en-US.title: The paint made from oyster shells could cool your home by 7ยฐC
en-US.body: Cool Roof France (CRF) uses discarded oyster shells to create thermo-reflective roof paint that reduces building temperatures by up to seven degrees Celsius. This innovation cuts energy consumption for air conditioning by 30-50%. CRF has successfully applied this paint to various buildings, including hospitals and offices, and it can also help counter the urban heat island effect. For those interested, CRF sells this paint online and allocates 10% of profits to support projects in heat-vulnerable regions like Senegal. This sustainable approach offers a promising way to cool buildings, conserve energy, and aid communities in a warming world.

en-US.title: ๐ Major win: Young climate activists score historic victory in US court
en-US.body: A US court has ruled that children have a constitutional right to a healthy environment in a landmark climate change trial in Montana. The case, led by young plaintiffs aged five to 22, argued that the state was violating their constitutional rights by permitting fossil fuel development without considering its environmental impact, particularly greenhouse gas emissions. This marks the first US court ruling against a government for violating constitutional rights linked to climate change. While it sets a crucial precedent, immediate impacts are limited, and the state plans to appeal the decision.

en-US.title: ๐ณ Trees and renewables help India slash emissions rate by 33%
en-US.body: India has achieved a remarkable 33% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions over 14 years, thanks to increased renewable energy, forest growth, and improved emissions intensity. This aligns with India's commitment to the United Nations Convention on Climate Change to reduce emissions intensity by 45% from 2005 levels by 2030. The annual emissions reduction rate reached 3% between 2016 and 2019, primarily due to government support for renewables, despite fossil fuels remaining a significant part of the energy mix. This progress should ease pressure from developed nations to reduce coal use. Forest expansion and green hydrogen initiatives have also played a role. Although the report awaits federal cabinet approval, India's emissions reduction efforts are noteworthy on the global climate stage.

en-US.title: ๐งโ๐ง How to set up a repair cafe from someone whoโs done it
en-US.body: Tunbridge Wells Repair Cafe, led by Chris Murphy, is a community initiative that repairs broken items at no cost. Repair cafes, a global movement inspired by Dutch environmentalist Martine Postma in 2009, encourage people to bring their broken items for volunteers to fix. Setting up a repair cafe doesn't require oversight, but Repair Cafe International offers a digital starter kit for a voluntary fee. Tunbridge Wells Repair Cafe operates on donations and has streamlined visitor registration with an online system. They repair various items, from electronics to textiles, relying on volunteers of all ages, including retirees and young enthusiasts. The cafe's mission is to reduce waste, promote sustainability, and foster a sense of community.
